Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the video represents the new American government, when in fact it was a recording from a City of Lake Worth commission meeting in Florida in 2014.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the individuals leaving the room before the prayer started were Christians, without any evidence to support this assumption.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that the video represents the new American government. It is based on a single video from a local commission meeting and does not provide any broader context or evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the video, which is that it was a recording of an invocation delivered by an atheist individual, rather than a representation of the new American government praying to Satan.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the video was recorded in 2014 and does not represent the current American government.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on the misleading information and biased views of Femi Fani-Kayode, who has a history of sharing misinformation and supporting false claims.
Understate: There is no significant understatement bias in the claim.
